docs.snippet: The Intel Corporation sued Advanced Micro Devices Inc. and the Cyrix Corporation on Friday, accusing them of infringing on the MMX trademark it has adopted for its multimedia-enhanced Pentium chip.     The lawsuit filed in United States District C...
docs.abstract: Intel Corp sues Advanced Micro Devices Inc and Cyrix Corp, charging they infringe on MMX trademark it has adopted for its multimedia-enhanced Pentium chip (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: The Intel Corporation sued Advanced Micro Devices Inc. and the Cyrix Corporation on Friday, accusing them of infringing on the MMX trademark it has adopted for its multimedia-enhanced Pentium chip. The lawsuit filed in United States District Court in Wilmington, Del., seeks an injunction against Advanced Micro Devices and Cyrix, as well as unspecified damages and fees, Intel said in a statement.

headline.main: Intel Files Suit Against Two Smaller Rivals On Pentium Chip Rights

docs.snippet: NOT long ago, traditional media companies were said to be dinosaurs in the new-media world of the Internet -- out of step, useless, probably endangered. But today, the old-media reptiles are looking increasingly attractive as partners to some of t...
docs.abstract: Technology column notes that old-media companies are looking increasingly attractive as partners to some of more popular sites on World Wide Web; cites CBS's recent purchase of 22 percent stake in Sportsline USA, in exchange for advertising, promotion and programming over five years; says even most successful Internet media companies need backing of established media companies to enlarge their audience and build profitable on-line businesses; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: NOT long ago, traditional media companies were said to be dinosaurs in the new-media world of the Internet -- out of step, useless, probably endangered. But today, the old-media reptiles are looking increasingly attractive as partners to some of the more popular sites on the World Wide Web. Last week, Sportsline USA sold a 22 percent stake to CBS in a deal valued at $100 million. The network, a unit of Westinghouse Electric, acquired its holding in the on-line sports service in exchange for advertising, promotion and programming over five years. CBS also has an option to lift its stake to 33 percent with further investment, in cash.

headline.main: The old-media dinosaurs seem to be having a rebirth. Don't blame cloning.

docs.snippet: Northern Telecom Ltd. announced last week that John A. Roth, the telecommunications equipment company's chief operating officer, would become chief executive and president in October.    Mr. Roth, 54, would succeed Jean C. Monty, who is scheduled ...
docs.abstract: Northern Telecom Ltd names chief operating officer John A Roth chief executive and president, succeeding Jean C Monty, who will resign to join BCE Inc, which owns 51 percent of Northern (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Northern Telecom Ltd. announced last week that John A. Roth, the telecommunications equipment company's chief operating officer, would become chief executive and president in October. Mr. Roth, 54, would succeed Jean C. Monty, who is scheduled to resign the two posts to join BCE Inc., the holding company that owns 51 percent of Northern Telecom and all of Bell Canada.

headline.main: At Northern Telecom, New Chief Executive To Be President, Too

docs.snippet: THE seventh TED conference, which focuses on the convergence of Technology, Entertainment and Design, was held in Monterey, Calif., last week. As with many convergence-inspired CD-ROM and World Wide Web businesses hitting the wall, it was a group ...
docs.abstract: Denise Caruso column deplores low status of educational interactive media on CD-ROM or the Web, much of it the product of the amateur spirit rather than the market; says the only really good interactive media material produced in last decade or so has been educational; cites recent speech by Daniel J Boorstin on the importance of the amateur spirit; cartoon (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THE seventh TED conference, which focuses on the convergence of Technology, Entertainment and Design, was held in Monterey, Calif., last week. As with many convergence-inspired CD-ROM and World Wide Web businesses hitting the wall, it was a group in need of inspiration. Some may have found that inspiration from a talk given by Daniel J. Boorstin, the Librarian of Congress emeritus and self-described amateur historian. In a speech titled ''The Amateur Spirit and Its Enemies,'' Mr. Boorstin warned an audience filled with Type A executives against the worship of commercialization in their businesses. He reminded them that the word amateur came from the Latin ''amare'' (to love) and that it was passion, not just profit, that would make the frontiers of technology and media worth pursuing.

headline.main: A reminder of the passion of the amateur, and of his value to multimedia.

docs.snippet: NATHAN MYHRVOLD, one of the top executives at the Microsoft Corporation, handed a visitor a small, odd-shaped object from his office windowsill.         It was a plaster cast of the tiny brain pan of a Tyrannosaurus rex; Mr. Myhrvold said it remin...
docs.lead_paragraph: NATHAN MYHRVOLD, one of the top executives at the Microsoft Corporation, handed a visitor a small, odd-shaped object from his office windowsill. It was a plaster cast of the tiny brain pan of a Tyrannosaurus rex; Mr. Myhrvold said it reminded him how few fossil records the dinosaurs had left behind. And in a conceptual leap worthy of Mr. Myhrvold's training as a physicist, this thought set him to worrying about the Internet and the World Wide Web.

headline.main: Can the Web be a time capsule if no one is saving the information for posterity?

docs.snippet: SOFTKEY INTERNATIONAL INC. announced a hostile takeover bid last week, seeking to disrupt the Learning Company's proposed merger with Broderbund Software and bringing to a boil a long-simmering industry debate over the pricing and distribution of ...
docs.lead_paragraph: SOFTKEY INTERNATIONAL INC. announced a hostile takeover bid last week, seeking to disrupt the Learning Company's proposed merger with Broderbund Software and bringing to a boil a long-simmering industry debate over the pricing and distribution of consumer software. Broderbund and its would-be partner, the Learning Company, typify a business model based on high-priced, high-quality educational titles. Softkey takes a low-price approach in which, the company concedes, the quality of the software can be secondary to the quantity of sales.

headline.main: The software industry will decide if its future lies in quality or quantity.

docs.snippet: Speak the words ''electronic commerce'' and in most circles, the starry-eyed vision that comes to mind is of a sophisticated new computer system for selling goods to millions of on-line consumers without the costly overhead of a storefront. Win-wi...
docs.abstract: Delivery services say they are ill-equipped to handle onslaught if electronic commerce really catches on and consumer sales total $12 billion by 2002, as has been predicted; delivering single package to home is expensive, and cost becomes even higher when driver has to redeliver when consumer is not home; theft and fraud are growing problems in areas where drivers leave packages on doorsteps to save cost of redelivery; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Speak the words ''electronic commerce'' and in most circles, the starry-eyed vision that comes to mind is of a sophisticated new computer system for selling goods to millions of on-line consumers without the costly overhead of a storefront. Win-win, retail revolution, etc. But in their rush to outfit the Internet as a global shopping mall, investors and vendors may have overlooked a practical question that just might be a deal breaker:

headline.main: On-line sellers learn how to get packages from cyberspace to consumers.

docs.snippet: British Sky Broadcasting Group, canceling a second plan to enter Germany's satellite television market, said last week that it would pull out of a planned digital pay-television venture with the Kirch Group.    Shares in B Sky B, as the company is...
docs.abstract: British Sky Broadcasting Group cancels second plan to enter Germany's satellite television market, saying it will pull out of planned digital pay-television venture with Kirch Group (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: British Sky Broadcasting Group, canceling a second plan to enter Germany's satellite television market, said last week that it would pull out of a planned digital pay-television venture with the Kirch Group. Shares in B Sky B, as the company is known, fell as much as 4.2 percent after the announcement. On the London Stock Exchange, B Sky B closed at $:6.165, or $9.88, down 7 pence, or 1.1 percent.

headline.main: B Sky B Drops Second Bid to Crack German Satellite Television Market

docs.snippet: One of the most promising technologies to reduce emissions and increase fuel economy in cars and trucks moved a step closer to reality this week as two American auto companies entered into an unusual partnership.    The Chrysler Corporation and De...
docs.abstract: Chrysler Corp and Delphi Automotive Systems, giant parts division of General Motors Corp, will collaborate to build prototype car that will derive its power from fuel cells that produce electricity (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: One of the most promising technologies to reduce emissions and increase fuel economy in cars and trucks moved a step closer to reality this week as two American auto companies entered into an unusual partnership. The Chrysler Corporation and Delphi Automotive Systems, the giant parts division of the General Motors Corporation, will collaborate to build a prototype car that would derive its power not from an internal combustion engine, but from fuel cells that produce electricity.

headline.main: Electric-Powered Car Is on Drawing Board

docs.snippet: THOSE who have long believed that the computer will automate humans out of readin' and writin' as efficiently as it has with 'rithmetic may finally have a little something to worry about.    Earlier this month, at the Macworld Expo, Apple Computer...
docs.abstract: Technology column explores efforts to get computers to understand and parse documents written in real human language, not the clipped, arcane commands usually used with computers; describes Microsoft Word's Auto Summarize document filter (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THOSE who have long believed that the computer will automate humans out of readin' and writin' as efficiently as it has with 'rithmetic may finally have a little something to worry about. Earlier this month, at the Macworld Expo, Apple Computer Inc. demonstrated a document summarizer, still in its research labs, that boiled down an essay to a single sentence, one that made the essay's key point.

headline.main: Computer software to recognize and sensibly render human speech.
